awd_titl_txt: Model-based Systems Engineering Boot Camp: An Initiative to Integrate Current Systems Engineering Transformations into Workforce Development
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to the national need for well-educated engineers and technicians by supporting a workshop on model-based systems engineering for production engineering.  Models are simplified representations of ideas, relationships, structures, and other constructs.  Examples of models include graphs, diagrams, mathematical equations, and physical representations. Model-based systems engineering helps engineers better understand processes, make decisions, and predict outcomes.  This project will support a two-day bootcamp on model-based systems engineering that will be held in El Paso, Texas. The bootcamp will include industry experts on model-based systems engineering, faculty from two- and four-year colleges and universities across the country, scientists from national laboratories, and trainers who will facilitate the bootcamp activities. To attract additional participants, the investigators will advertise the bootcamp through systems engineering professional societies.  The bootcamp will produce white papers, model-based systems engineering training manuals, case studies, training examples, and printed workbooks. It will also develop guidelines for how to incorporate model-based systems engineering into curricula at all levels. A website will be used to provide the resulting open-access materials to any interested individual or organization.  It is expected that this bootcamp will lay a foundation for improving and expanding model-based systems engineering education to enhance the capabilities of the Nation's STEM workforce.

Model-based systems engineering is a systems engineering methodology that focuses on using models throughout a project life cycle, from design and development through operations.  More recently, this approach has also been useful for computer simulation experiments, to further overcome the gap between the system model specification and the respective simulation software. Model-based systems engineering has the potential to increase productivity by minimizing unnecessary manual transcription of concepts when coordinating the work of large teams. The application of model-based systems engineering to production engineering systems is novel and of increasing importance as production systems become more complex. This project will seek to increase workforce skills in this important area of engineering.  

This project is funded by NSF's EHR Core Research: Production Engineering Education and Research (ECR: PEER) program, which seeks to improve the education of future and current professionals in production engineering. It also aims to study the effectiveness of the innovative educational strategies adopted by these projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project improved the technical skills of the STEM workforce, academic faculty, and industry professionals by introducing them to Model-based Systems Engineering (MBSE).  Over a period of three years, the grant supported in: 

 Engaging with Subject Matter Experts to understand Model-based Systems Engineering Workforce Training Needs: this activity focused on reaching out to MBSE industry professionals in the United States to identify current industry workforce training needs for the future manufacturing and production engineering workforce. This activity was successfully conducted over two phases. In Phase 1 of the study, we surveyed 52 industry professionals from Defense, Aerospace, Automotive, Consultancy, Software, and IT industry clusters of the United States to identify MBSE tools, languages, and concepts preferred by industry professionals in a potential candidates for hire. This is followed by Phase 2 of the survey targeted at academic institutions with Systems and MBSE programs to analyze the extent to which MBSE curricula reflect industry workforce hiring requirements. To this end, 45 academic faculty were surveyed to collect data on MBSE tools and concepts introduced to students as a part of their curriculum and identify the challenges in teaching them to the students.  The analysis results were presented at the peer-reviewed IEEE Systems Engineering Conference (Akundi et al., 2022, Akundi et al., 2021, Akundi, Lopez, and Tseng, 2021) and the Complex Adaptive Systems Conference (Akundi and Lopez, 2021). Further, to reinforce the analysis, a study on the survey of the MBSE landscape was undertaken to identify the commonly referred to concepts and methodologies concerning MBSE, along with identifying commonalities across academia and industry practitioners' MBSE tools and methods. The results of this activity were published in peer–reviewed journal Systems Engineering (Akundi and Mondragon, 2021). This study further contributed to analyzing job openings from the International Council of Systems Engineering’s CAB Members to capture current needs in terms of role description lifecycle experience, tools, and methodologies needed in the job market, and explored the relationship of systems engineering methodologies covered in Hispanic-Serving Institutions. This study was presented at the 2022 Annual ASEE conference (Luna et al., 2022). This initiative

 Hosting a two-day MBSE Training Bootcamp: A core of this project, this initiative is focused on developing and conducting a Model-based Systems Engineering (MBSE) Bootcamp. Due to COVID-19, the face-2-face format of the Bootcamp was moved towards making this event online. The intent of the Bootcamp and its agenda were disseminated to participants using INCOSE, ASEE, and professional membership chapters along with the help of the Texas Manufacturing Assistance center for engaging a wider audience from manufacturing and production engineering backgrounds. A total of 159 participants attended the Bootcamp on both days, with geographical distribution of 93 participants from the United States, 61 from Mexico, two from Spain, one from Portugal, one from India, and one from Brazil. The distribution of the participant affiliation included 53% from academia (comprising both faculty and students) and the rest from industries, with 23% from manufacturing, 11% from aerospace and defense, 6% from software, 3% from hospitality, 2% from transportation and distribution, and 1% each from telecommunications, and energy and utilities.

Day one of the Bootcamp included a workshop and keynote panel from Lockheed Martin that introduced participants to different models and simulations addressing other purposes and needs, type, fidelity, and the complexity of their abstractions and analyses. In addition, all the workshop participants were introduced to models and simulations used to support the entire system life cycle through MBSE. Day 2 of the Bootcamp started with an introduction to the importance of modeling and simulation using the SIMIO tool for modeling, visualizing, and analyzing manufacturing systems for improving business operations. The workshop concluded by exploring the benefits of recent disruptive technologies that provide exceptional support for digital transformations. Participants completing the Bootcamp were awarded a certificate indicating their familiarity with the SIMIO tool. These digital certifications were awarded to enable the participants to display their credentials on social media platforms such as linked-in and Twitter. The analysis of the Bootcamp and the content used was presented at the peer-reviewed IEEE Systems Engineering Conference (Akundi et al., 2022). Data analysis indicated a positive gain of MBSE knowledge among the participants. The workshop presentations, training materials, and recordings are all available to the public via the project webpage (https://www.utrgv.edu/nsfmbse/). Academic institutions can use the workshop materials to introduce MBSE to academic and professional communities of practice.
